title: Pair of Candlesticks

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of silver-plated bronze.

description: In 1900 Robert Riddle Jarvie began advertising himself as “the Candlestick Maker.” He produced 16 different designs, each named after a Greek letter. These elongated candlesticks take inspiration from natural flower forms, reflecting the influence of the English Arts and Crafts movement. Jarvie also fashioned hollowware reminiscent of medieval forms and incorporated spare, geometric ornament and Celtic-inspired script into his designs.
inscriptions: Engraved in script on base of one candlestick: Jarvie / I
credit_line: Bessie Bennett and Mrs. Herbert Stern funds
publication_history: David A. Hanks, “Robert R. Jarvie, Chicago Silversmith,” Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 68, 3 (May–June 1974), 15–19 (ill.). David A. Hanks, “Robert R. Jarvie, Chicago Silversmith,” Magazine Antiques 110, 3 (Sept. 1976), 522–23, fig. 1. Patricia Patton, "The Work of Robert Riddle Jarvie: American Arts and Crafts Metalsmith" (M.A. thesis, Cooper–Hewitt Museum/Parsons School of Design, 1991), no. 11. Elyse Zorn Karlin, "The Arts and Crafts Jewelry Movement in Europe" (Schiffer, 1992), ill. Judith A. Barter, "The Prairie School and Decorative Arts at the Art Institute of Chicago" Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies 21, 2 (1995), 112–133, cat. 23 (ill.) Elyse Zorn Karlin, "Jewelry and Metalwork in the Arts and Crafts Tradition," (Atglen, PA: Schiffer, 2004, 2nd ed.), 241 (ill.). Judith A. Barter et al., American Arts at The Art Institute of Chicago: From Colonial Times to World War I (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1998), 309–311, no. 158. Judith A. Barter, Elizabeth McGoey, et al., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2016), cat. 75. Elizabeth McGoey, ed., American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 2018), https://publications.artic.edu/americansilver/reader/collection/section/6, cat. 75 (ill.). Barbara Schnitzer, "The Lives and Times of Three Chicago Metalsmiths," The Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 13, 2020, https://www.artic.edu/articles/869/the-lives-and-times-of-three-chicago-metalsmiths, (ill.).
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Apostles of Beauty: Arts and Crafts from Britain to Chicago, Nov. 7, 2009–Jan. 31, 2010, cat. 60 (ill.).
provenance_text: Macklowe Gallery, New York City, by 1973; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1973.
